description:
Rickettsia hoogstraalii is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Rickettsia. It is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular pathogen that is primarily associated with ticks as its vector and reservoir host.

Rickettsia hoogstraalii was first identified in 1984 and was named after the Dutch entomologist Harry Hoogstraal, who made significant contributions to the study of ticks and tick-borne diseases.

This species of Rickettsia is known to infect various tick species, including Dermacentor andersoni, Dermacentor variabilis, and Amblyomma americanum, which are common in North America. The bacteria can be transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected tick, leading to a tick-borne illness known as rickettsiosis.

The clinical symptoms associated with Rickettsia hoogstraalii infection in humans can include fever, headache, muscle aches, and a characteristic rash. However, the pathogenicity and clinical significance of this species in human health are not yet fully understood, and further research is ongoing to elucidate its epidemiological and public health importance.
